children.subject: This is as an example of an opportunity cost to studying abroad to go along with all the wonderful experiences you will have.  We will not displace students who would otherwise have gotten into 161 to accommodate exceptions like the one suggested above.

+1 Would there be special exceptions made for students who will not have another chance to take the course? I am studying abroad next fall and graduating after that, so next semester is my last semester to take it but since I'm currently a junior who just got senior standing this semester, I am very low on the waitlist.

history.content: I don't remember us processing the waitlist for 161 by any application ever since the course was created.  Perhaps you are referring to the way we used to process enrollments for CS160?

children.subject:
"Manually" means that we will follow the criteria described here:  http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Policies/enrollment.shtml
In the event that any other criteria are followed, like happened in the past for 160, we list those criteria on schedule.berkeley.edu and the course website.

Right, that's the essence of the question.  Last time I enrolled in a course where the waitlist was processed manually, it was for CS160 and I ended up not getting in because waitlist position did not matter.  Since I'm in a similar situation, I was wondering what 'manually' entailed as per the CS 161 waitlist.

history.content: Hi, I'm 97 on the waitlist for CS 161 next semester, with 246 / 350 currently enrolled.  Normally I'd be cool with that, but last time the waitlist was processed manually (declared CS at the time), I didn't get enrolled because the professor decided to issue applications (?) instead of going by the waitlist order.  Does anyone have any more specific information about the way the waitlist will be processed?
history.subject: 161 Waitlist processed manually
